title: 107_s1539
content: The Act is titled "Protecting America's Children Against Terrorism Act" and includes an amendment to the Public Health Service Act to implement public health measures to protect against terrorism. The "Protecting America's Children Against Terrorism Act" establishes a National Task Force on Children and Bioterrorism, composed of various officials and experts in child health and related fields. The National Task Force on Children and Bioterrorism, including representatives from children's health organizations, will make recommendations to the Secretary on the preparedness of the US healthcare system to respond to bioterrorism targeting children and youth. The National Task Force on Children and Bioterrorism will recommend changes to the healthcare system to respond to bioterrorist attacks on children and youth, including protocols for mass casualties. The Secretary will establish a Children and Terrorism Information Network to provide information on preparing for biological or chemical terrorist attacks to health providers, community centers, and schools. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding for subsequent years. The Secretary will provide supplies for children in push packs under the National Pharmaceutical Stockpile Program. $50,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding for subsequent years. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities to enhance 2-1-1 call centers or other hotlines for disaster response and social services support for children and families in crisis. Eligible entities must be non-profit organizations working to expand these services. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act include redesignating sections related to clinical research. SEC. 409I. Pediatric studies of drugs and biologics, including vaccines, for illnesses and injuries caused by biological or chemical agents used in warfare and terrorism. The Secretary is required to develop and maintain a list of drugs and biologics, including vaccines, for pediatric testing to prevent and treat illnesses caused by biological or chemical agents used in warfare or terrorism. Additionally, a plan must be developed annually to ensure timely pediatric testing and labeling of these agents, coordinating with existing laws and regulations. The Secretary may award contracts to entities with expertise to conduct pediatric clinical trials for drugs and biologics, including vaccines used to prevent and treat illnesses caused by biological or chemical agents in acts of warfare or terrorism. $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding as needed for subsequent years. The Secretary may award contracts for pediatric clinical trials for drugs and biologics, including vaccines for illnesses caused by biological or chemical agents in acts of warfare or terrorism. $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding as needed for subsequent years. Training provisions in the Public Health Service Act are amended to exclude section 770A. "Training for pediatric issues related to biological and chemical agents used in warfare and terrorism is covered in section 770A." The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for education and training of clinicians in pediatric consequences of biological and chemical agents, as well as for developing educational materials on the topic. Eligible entities include children's hospitals, pediatric units, and professional organizations. Applicants must submit an application containing required information. $50,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding as needed for subsequent years. SEC. 4124 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 addresses school evacuations, safe places, and parental notifications. The Secretary must develop recommendations and models for school evacuation plans, safe places for children during attacks, partnerships with the medical community, and parental notification procedures. These will be disseminated to local school districts nationwide. Authorization of Appropriations: $1,000,000 for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding as needed for subsequent years, to support health provider and public health communities. Amounts allocated will remain available until expended. "Authorization of $1,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 to support mental health services for children and their caregivers." The Secretary, along with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will award grants to eligible entities to develop and implement comprehensive mental health services for children, school faculty, and child care providers affected by terrorist attacks, times of war, or other major crises. Eligible entities include local educational agencies, community-based organizations, community mental health organizations, professional organizations, or partnerships of such entities. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of comprehensive mental health services for children, school faculty, and child care providers affected by crises. $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding as needed for subsequent years. Amounts appropriated will remain available until expended. SEC. 411. CHILDREN'S ASSISTANCE. This section provides authorization of appropriations for comprehensive mental health services for children, school faculty, and child care providers affected by crises. $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding as needed for subsequent years. Amounts appropriated will remain available until expended. Upon a determination by the President in a disaster area, a Children's Coordinating Officer will be appointed to ensure immediate care and transition for children who have lost their parents. The Officer will collaborate with government agencies and organizations to provide necessary assistance and services to children and their caregivers. The Children's Coordinating Officer appointed in a disaster area will provide immediate temporary care services, counseling on long-term permanency planning, legal services for guardianships and adoptions, information on available services for disaster victims, and mental health services to children and their caregivers.
